name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Fire Emblem Design and Analysis
base_name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Fire Emblem Design and Analysis
long_desc: Fire Emblem is one of Nintendos longestrunning franchises. From the olden days of Marth on the NES to debates about whether Edelgard did nothing wrong, Fire Emblem has undergone numerous evolutions in gameplay and story. But how did these changes come about Why did Kouhei Maeda introduce face petting and ship wars Is Seth really the most broken unit in the series And are the crests really to blame   This course will seek to answer those questions and more. In Fire Emblem Design and Analysis, students will gain a deeper understanding of the game design, mechanics, and writing of Fire Emblem series. Through examining similarities and differences in these aspects of game design throughout the series, students will gain a deeper understanding of overarching principles of game design and strategy. Specifically, this course will look at unit and character design, the evolution of game mechanics eg durability, skills, the weapon triangle, weapon weight throughout the series, common unit archetypes and tropes, the bases vs growth debate and the optimal way to play Fire Emblem, the lore and storyline of various Fire Emblem games both good and bad, and character writing through supports.

custom_fields.goals: Explain how Fire Emblem mechanics have changed and been introduced throughout the series, such as weapon weight, skills, Holy Blood, etc. Understand the basics of efficient play and what makes a unit good or bad. Explain the principles of chapter design and provide examples. Explain the debate between bases and growths. Explain how permadeath and RNG affect gameplay, as well as how they contribute to series themes. Understand the principles of effective character and story writing in Fire Emblem. Understand the lore of various Fire Emblem settings. Explain how various FE games integrate gameplay and story.
custom_fields.key_topics:
This course will cover:
- Unit and character design
- Chapter design
- Common Unit Archetypes
- Evolution of game mechanics (durability, skills, etc)
- Efficient gameplay and resource usage
- What makes a particular unit "good" or "bad"
- Lore and storyline of various FE games
- Themes and morally grey characters
- Supports, character writing, relationships
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should ideally have some level of prior exposure to Fire Emblem greater than "have played Marth in Smash". Detailed game knowledge is not necessary - that will be taught in class! - but some familiarity with basic mechanics will be helpful.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Students will be assessed through weekly multiple-choice lecture quizzes, due before the start of the next class on Canvas, one midterm project, and one final project, both of which will be assigned 3 weeks in advance and either delivered as an in-class presentation or submitted as an essay.
custom_fields.relevance: Whether you're a Fire Emblem newbie or a series veteran, this course will hopefully give you some new knowledge on Fire Emblem game design and writing. Through this course, students will be able to go beyond the games themselves and dive into the gameplay and story choices made by IS.
custom_fields.learning_resources:
Most materials will be provided via Canvas. When students need to reference specific chapter, character, or script data, students may use online reference sites such as the Fire Emblem Wiki, Serenesforest.net, and FEUniverse. Links to these sites can be found in Canvas.

Gameplay and story analyses by YouTubers such as Mekkah, ActualLizard, and Ghast may also be useful. Links to relevant videos will be provided via Canvas as necessary throughout the course.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Students will complete weekly lecture quizzes (~5 mins), a mid-term project (~1 hour preparation, 5 mins in class) and a final project (~1 hour preparation, 5 mins in class).
